message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms consistent with cluster headaches, including severe unilateral pain, diaphoresis, rhinorrhea, and lacrimation. Ibuprofen alone may not be sufficient to manage the pain. Subcutaneous sumatriptan is a first-line treatment for cluster headaches and should be administered in this case. Verapamil may be used as prophylaxis for cluster headaches but is not a first-line treatment for acute attacks. CT angiography and deep brain stimulation are not indicated in the initial management of cluster headaches.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest cluster headache, which is often treated with sumatriptan. Verapamil may be used for prophylaxis, but it would not provide immediate relief in the acute setting. CT angiography would not be necessary in this case as there is no evidence of a hemorrhage or mass on CT head. Deep brain stimulation is a more invasive treatment option for refractory cases and would not be the first-line option.

CT angiography and deep brain stimulation are not indicated in the management of cluster headaches.

Sumatriptan is a drug used to treat cluster headaches and would be the next best step in management. CT angiography is not indicated at this time as there is no evidence of intracranial masses or hemorrhage. Deep brain stimulation is a last resort treatment and is not indicated at this time.

Verapamil is also an effective prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches, but it should not be the next step in management during an acute attack. CT angiography would not be helpful in the current scenario, as the non-contrast CT of the head already ruled out intracranial masses or hemorrhage. Deep brain stimulation of the posterior inferior hypothalamus is a treatment option for refractory cluster headaches, but it is not the next best step in initial management.
